title: Question 83

children: A 32-year-old woman is evaluated in the hospital for a 3-week history of progressive shortness of breath, arthralgia, and fatigue. Her only medication is pantoprazole for gastroesophageal reflux disease. Medical history is significant for Raynaud phenomenon treated with cold avoidance. She works in an accounting firm and has no unusual environmental exposures.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg, pulse rate is 98/min, and respiration rate is 24/min.

children.referenceRange: Blood gases, Oxygen saturation, arterial (ambient air)

children: is 90% breathing oxygen, 2 L/min by nasal cannula. Auscultation reveals crackles at both lung bases. She has puffy-appearing fingers. The remainder of the examination is normal.
Chest radiograph shows bilaterally increased markings with a basilar predominance without lymphadenopathy.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

text.__html: Connective tissue disease–associated interstitial lung disease

children: Interstitial lung disease is common among patients with connective tissue disease and can occasionally be the first manifestation.
Most patients with systemic sclerosis–related lung disease have a nonspecific interstitial pneumonia pattern characterized by ground-glass opacities with predominance at the base of the lungs.
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is interstitial lung disease (ILD) associated with connective tissue disease (

). ILD is common among patients with connective tissue disease and can occasionally be the first manifestation. In this patient, systemic sclerosis is suggested by the presence of Raynaud phenomenon, gastroesophageal reflux disease, “puffy fingers” (a finding of early skin disease), and positive antitopoisomerase I (anti-Scl-70) antibody. A patulous esophagus can be seen on the chest CT scan. Radiographic findings mirror those of other idiopathic interstitial pneumonias, with the nonspecific interstitial pneumonia pattern characterized by ground-glass opacities with predominance at the base of the lungs seen in this patient. This radiographic pattern is present in more than 80% of persons with systemic sclerosis–associated ILD. In patients with diffuse parenchymal lung disease, the presence of an underlying connective tissue disease has prognostic and therapeutic implications. In contrast to idiopathic interstitial pneumonia, patients with connective tissue disease–associated ILD are treated with immunomodulatory medications and tend to have a more favorable prognosis.

High-resolution CT imaging of the chest shows findings of ground-glass opacities and centrilobular micronodules that are mid- and upper-lung predominant. However, this patient's chest radiographic findings, lack of environmental exposures, and findings of systemic sclerosis make the diagnosis of hypersensitivity pneumonitis unlikely.

) is the most common idiopathic interstitial pneumonia. It occurs predominantly in older persons; the diagnosis of IPF is rare in those younger than 50 years of age. Gradual onset of dyspnea and cough over months to years is typical.

) is a granulomatous disease of unknown cause that can affect multiple organ systems, including the lungs. Frequent radiographic findings of sarcoidosis include lymphadenopathy and the presence of nodules along bronchovascular bundles. This patient's radiographic findings are not consistent with sarcoidosis.

objective.__html: Diagnose connective tissue disease–associated interstitial lung disease.
